>>177860877
score is unfortunately mostly just re-using the one from the 1st movie. Not really any new themes, or at least any that stick. It's a bit like TLJ or RoS compared to TFA, and TFA only had 1 new theme. But the "remixes" can be quite good. So serviceable score but not memorable.

And he would hit kids with a pointer stick on the hand or they could go to the principle. At Halloween he would tie one of those tootsie pop ghosts to the end of his pointer stick with a length of fishing line and he would hover the little ghost in your face and threaten you sincerely with the little ghost bobbing around. >>177870762

The Jack character's reference to the "white man's burden" is loaded with several meanings. The phrase itself refers to the Kipling poem, while Jack uses it contextually to refer to alcohol. These are easily read together with the absent native Americans who previously inhabited the land, in a now-famliar trope about native American curses (Poltergeist).

The Kipling poem itself is taken to refer to the "White man's burden", the moral task to civilize the rest of the non-white world via imperialism, colonialism, conversion to Christianity, and so forth. Alcohol is also a burden borne by white men (and many others), as Jack is an alcoholic who is "on the job", and relaxing. Specifically, and in the American context, alcohol is a burden which white men are capable of shouldering (because they are civilized), while the uncivilized are not. White men can handle their liquor (never mind Jack's history, which shows the opposite). One of the major reasons for the humiliation and total defeat of the native Americans (who were "repelled" from the Overlook's site, cheerily noted by Ullman) is that they are almost unique in human culture in never having cultivated any sort of rot juice which generates alcohol and which gets you fucked up. It wasn't until the white man came along that they got a taste of the fire water, and that together with several other factors ruined them.

Jack is upholding himself as a member of orderly white society. The Overlook's employees, living and dead, are (mostly) white men, upholding the hotel (America/the West) itself, conquered and against the colonized. I realize that this sort of racial/colonial reading is tiresome these days, but it's unironically one of the clear subtexts in the movie. Jack styles himself as "one of the good guys" but of course he's scum. The exact nature of why he's scum can be discussed.

When you watch the thing, you actually feel for Lloyd, watching this awful man rationalize, confess being an asshole.

posts.com:
Paul Blart was just an ordinary man, living an ordinary life. He worked as a security officer at the local mall, patrolling the aisles and keeping an eye on things. But one day, everything changed.

It started with a strange rash on Paul's neck. At first, he thought it was just a bug bite, but it quickly spread all over his body. The rash became inflamed and painful, making it difficult for Paul to move or even think.

As the rash worsened, Paul began to experience strange hallucinations. He saw grotesque, twisted creatures that seemed to be made out of his own flesh. These creatures would whisper to him, telling him to do things that went against his nature.

Paul tried to ignore the voices, but they became more and more persistent. He felt his mind slipping, and soon he found himself doing things that he would never have done before. He began to harm others, using his security officer uniform and equipment to inflict pain and terror on those around him.

As the infection spread, Paul's body began to change. His skin became thick and leathery, and his muscles bulged and twisted. He grew sharp claws and fangs, and his eyes glowed with a sickly green light. He was no longer Paul Blart, the mall security officer. He was a monster, a creature of pure terror.

The authorities were powerless to stop him. They tried to kill him, but he was too powerful. He was a being of pure destruction, a force that could not be contained.

As the days went by, Paul continued to wreak havoc on the mall and the surrounding suburbs. He was a nightmare that would not end, a horror that would haunt the people of the town for generations to come.

And as the people fled in terror, Paul Blart laughed, his twisted, monstrous face contorted into a grotesque grin. He had become something beyond human, something that defied all laws of nature and science. He was a true horror, a creature of unimaginable power.

it’s strange being in these spaces, where everyone is some degree of schizoid or antisocial, feels lonely in a different way.
I don’t think it’s very normal anymore, but might still be somewhat common. there isn’t much tangible reward for groups sticking together, with the way we socialize now.

>>177852619
>so was it that they didn't have enough life boats or just didn't fill them up properly or both? Or all 3?
They didn't have enough lifeboats but it's not clear that it even would have mattered. They intentionally down-played the severity of the situation so as to not "create panic". When they loaded the lifeboats, the Captain did not order women and children to board them. They asked for "volunteers". Hence, they literally had trouble finding enough people willing to get in the boats and that's ultimately why they were launched half-full. Once they were launched, they were effectively under the command of the men on board and most of them quite rationally refused to return since by about 90-minutes in, a palpable panic and disorder began to take hold.

Also, read about the Captain and crew of the Carpathia who answered the call to rescue. Heroic story.

>>177853656
spoiler-ish free review?

for me I started due to nostalgia from the 90s movies.
Wednesday has always been a character that has a scene set up for her to deliver an one-liner, we laugh, and the scene is over.
Maybe had a little less than a third of these movies deticated to her, so maybe 25-30 minutes.
The transition to carry 8 episodes of 50 minutes was harsh.

I watched one episode, a few days later the second, then a few days later again I did have the time to watch the center 4 consecutively, then the last two on two separate days again.

In the beginning my biggest gribe was that the rest of the family was simply not present and the new characters barely endeared themselves to me.
Maybe after episode three I kinda got the flow going and had an enjoyable time with it.
But then mysteriies the show set up started to get revealed in rather disappointing ways and Wednesday herself became (intentionally by the screenwriters) rather unsympathetic, managing to push her "friends" away to nobody's surprise so she could regret it in a moment of introspection.
But that moment flies away, she barely admits to have been wrong once and everything is fine and dandy because at least the plot was wrapped up and didn't leave a stupid cliffhanger

Male characters are either sorta crushing on her, omegas, related or cartoonish villains.
I would blame it on a female writing staff... if they were responsible for those episodes, but nope. Out of 8 episodes 4 were written by women, and those were the ones I liked, the other 4 that were written by men I didn't

cinematography and use of camera was done well sometimes, but I barely can count on my fingers when I thought it was good, rest was just fine.

>>177853656
>is it good?
it's a pretty comfy show, and is a good watching experience that kept me interested, however the show has some glaring issues that need to be addressed in the next season.

My biggest gripe is the visual style. The costumes, set pieces, and school are all beautiful and fitting for the show. However the show itself ends up looking like Hannah Montana because of the sparse color grading done to the shots. I am not saying the show needs to be heavily filtered to look dark and gloomy, but it's TOO colorful for an Addams family show, and doesn't match the theme whatsoever.

The actual camerawork itself isn't incredibly interesting, and feels, again, like that of some Disney channel daytime show like iCarly. It needs work, needs transition shots, needs more interesting camera angles and whatnot to not feel so "cheap".

The show IS cheap, however, it's clearly not a big budget production. This isn't a huge issue but it shows, and I would like to see more effort in the visual style next season considering its success.

Plotwise I thought the show was fantastic. It's a mystery show where Wednesday is acting as the detective, investigating suspects for who might be killing people in the woods. During the season her relationship with her family and other people in her life are examined, and I liked that aspect a lot. I liked the scenes with her dad and uncle fester and thought everyone played their roles well.

My main issue with the plot is that I KNEW who the perpetrator was 15 minutes into the show when Thornhill is introduced with dirt on her boots right after a person is killed in the woods, it's too obvious a tell. And when we find out that Tyler is actually the Hyde, it just doesn't make that much sense - I felt like there wasn't enough proof to pin on him.

Next season I'd like to see the show be more clever, where Wednesday truly solves a crime Sherlock Holmes style by considering multiple pieces of evidence critically.

Good show, watch it.

>>177866722
1. If ever Crom answered a prayer, it would be to give a man a chance to fight, as Conan acknowledges in his prayer. Valeria also says she would come back even from death to fight with Conan. It could also have been a hallucination and the man was blinded by the sun. Look at Conan's face in reaction, it's a mystery, unknowable.
2. It's unknown, and again perhaps unknowable. I think the inability to attain certain knowledge of the world is a theme throughout the movie. Conan's father gives his answer to what the riddle is, that only steel is reliable. One good theory I've read is that Conan's father gets it wrong by trusting in steel, Thulsa Doom gets it wrong by concluding that the answer is that soft flesh is stronger than hard steel, but Conan realizes that true steel is in the will, and thus conquers them both. I like the theory anon poasted earlier in this thread that it's about turning your body & mind into steel through hardship. Personally, I think that there paradoxically is no answer, that as steel is made strong through assaying and forging, man is made strong through adversity and specifically through seeking the answer to the riddle of steel. A man who thinks he has found the answer becomes content, as Conan's father did before Thulsa Doom, in quest of the riddle, killed him ("when I was younger I sought it too"), and as Thulsa Doom himself did before Conan slew him in turn. To stop seeking the riddle is to die with an (inevitably wrong) answer ("if I die, I will have to go before Crom and he will ask me, 'what is the riddle of steel?' If I don't know it, he will cast me out of Valhalla and laugh at me"), thus to live is to seek the riddle of steel and forge oneself stronger. That which does not kill me...
3. The sorcerer was pulling his soul back into his body, from hell? the beyond? Valhall? The nature of the spirits or demons is another unknowable, something that would break the mind of one who tried to comprehend them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>177869666
Out of characters so continuing: Robert E. Howard was friends and penpals with H.P. Lovecraft, and they included references to one another's works. There is some mind-breaking Lovecraftian shit in Conan stories. Most people flee from them in mad terror and in some of the earlier stories like Phoenix on the Sword and God in the Bowl even Conan's sanity teeters on the edge in facing these otherworldly horrors. The essential incomprehensibility of the true nature of the world to the (sane) human mind pervades both the stories and the film. Magicians like Thulsa Doom and the chronicler are at least half-mad as a consequence of the secret knowledge they wield.

It's Milius's best and one of my favorite movies of all time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Shoplifters of the World > Licorice Pizza
Stephen Kijak’s tribute to The Smiths captures the inextinguishable flame of pop-culture fraternity, going deeper than Paul Thomas Anderson’s clever ’70s period piece.

>France > Drive My Car
Bruno Dumont’s media heroine reveals contemporary psychic turmoil while Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s Chekhov imitation distracts from it. Dumont mixes genres to pungent effect while Hamaguchi tells the wrong story and lards it with “art.”

>Summer of 85 > Belfast
François Ozon revisits ’80s AIDS-era innocence for a bold cultural confession, while Kenneth Branagh turns Irish ethnic conflict into totally inauthentic pop nostalgia.

>Sin > Benedetta, House of Gucci
Andrei Mikhalkov-Konchalovsky’s awesome Michelangelo biopic explores the price and sacrifice of achieving greatness. Paul Verhoeven and Ridley Scott exploit the business of religion and fashion for shameless Euro-trash.

>Zack Snyder’s Justice League, Army of the Dead, Army of Thieves > No Time to Die
Snyder finally got his chance to fulfill the visionary possibilities of pop myths, but the James Bond franchise-holders kill off the formerly fun, expressive brand.

>Georgetown > The Card Counter
Christoph Waltz’s unsparing Beltway satire is more humane than Paul Schrader’s wallow in way-late recriminations about the Iraq War.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Love Is Love Is Love > Passing, The Lost Daughter
Eleanor Coppola’s wisdom about female experience is missing from Rebecca Hall’s and Maggie Gyllenhaal’s miserable tales about racial and gender identity. Coppola doesn’t fit the feminist model, she transcends it.

>Saint-Narcisse > The Power of the Dog
Bruce LaBruce dares explore the mystique of sexual identity, creating his own, rich mythology, but Jane Campion demeans the Western genre as if to justify the misandry and homophobia of pseudo-feminism.

>Sublet > Parallel Mothers
Eytan Fox forces a haughty New York Times journalist in Israel to rethink his place in the world, but Almodóvar’s bisexual melodrama turns his usual charm into a pretext for lamenting Spain’s Fascist past. Remarkable compassion vs. embarrassing guilt.

>Licorice Pizza > The Worst Person in the World
Anderson’s wild, evocative anecdotes about freewheeling youth best Joachim Trier’s exploits that tirelessly defend self-obsessed Millennials. It’s the difference between romance and cynicism.

>Dear Comrades! > The Tragedy of Macbeth
Konchalovsky’s view of recent Soviet history (featuring a powerful performance by Yuliya Vysotskaya) parallels the contemporary U.S. Communist threat, but Joel Coen traduces Shakespeare to flatter contemporary U.S. political trends. A vibrant history lesson vs. a lesson in thespian vanity.

>Pig > King Richard
Nicolas Cage’s artisan-avenger makes Michael Sarnoski’s folktale a fable about personal conviction, but Will Smith misses the point in his latest egotistical biopic.

Criticize Paul Anderson at your own peril. He is a master filmmaker. A visionary. He's Cameron, Miller, Scott, and Snyder, without the ego.

Death Race is one of the most important films of its genre. It took cars and made them visceral. It took racing and made it cruel. The glimmer that existed in videogames like Twisted Metal was paired with the corporate cynicism of Running Man to fill the screen to bursting with roaring engines, chattering guns, and the visceral spray of blood. Without Death Race there can be no Fury Road, and in that sense Fury Road can be seen as an overhyped imitation that brings little to the table itself, other than costing 4x more to make.

What exactly did There Will Be Blood do for cinema as a medium?

The concept becomes self-defeating inherently.
As soon as you say, "we're going to do adult superheroes", you kill the concept of the superhero.
Either you end up having to explain away why the world isn't controlled by a cadre of genetic ubermenschen unless your superheroes are all weak or explicitly have uninheritable powers. Either way this leads into the second part where you have to fail to justify why the CIA/KGB/MSS doesn't own all the coolest superheroes and it stops being a tale of heroism, but instead becomes a story about superpowered black ops acting as agents of the State.
Which is just Watchmen.

Its not interesting or cool or whatever. It kills itself.
Superheroes exist as a means to tell larger than life morality tales. Good clean fun for kids.
Anything else only becomes self-sabatoging as the contradictions and conflicts within the concept become relevant.

Fantasy has the benefit of building its own society to set its story in.
Commonly fantasy books or series will explicitly say that the world is stratified into castes dependent on personal power or genetic heritage. That those with the most power are often abusive or disinterested in the fates of the commoners.
With powerful warlords or monarchs having the strongest forces on call.

Fantasy deals with those contradictions far better than superhero works do. Because superhero works are beholden to our setting and world. For Superman to be work, he has to be set in a relatively grounded world. And that means that as soon as you break that veil of naivete, you have to deal with grounded and unpleasant real world questions.

posts.com:
While most small arms don't seem to hurt Terminators, and according to Kyle he wouldn't be able to destroy one "with these weapons", Terminators can't just stand and tank hits, and can get knocked down with enough force.

In the police station shootout, the Terminator only takes a few hits from AR-15s, and gets more "tactical" once they're broken out. IE he doesn't just stand still and take shots repeatedly.

Presumably armor-piercing ammunition or especially powerful small arms could damage a Terminator. How many soldiers would it take, with conventional weapons, to destroy one?

posts.com:
>>177867184
The narrative requires it to be an unstoppable killing machine so to that purpose, in the context of a movie, there's no number of guys that could stand between it and a 1v1 showdown with its target.

Realistically, depending on their equipment, training, and knowledge of the enemy, and on the terrain, a squad-size element could do it or certainly a platoon. An M16/M4 shoots little 5.56mm rounds that won't punch through the heavy steel parts, but they will pierce the flesh and become little pieces of metal that will get stuck in the moving parts of the T-800. The eyes are also vulnerable, a bunch of shots to the head and some will pierce the glass eyes it uses to see and enter the electronic components inside the head. Shrapnel-producing grenades will absolutely fuck this thing up for the same reason, a bunch of little chunks of metal flying everywhere will get caught inside all the complex moving parts and render it immobile, and the shockwave of explosions and the impact of projectiles will still damage the comparatively delicate electronics inside just by shaking it around enough. An anti-tank recoilless rifle would destroy a T-800 and a Barrett M82 or other anti-materiel rifle will probably do so as well.

>>177865088
there was a thing in the book that tied it all together (the movie is better).
When the apes touch the monolith one of the apes gets the idea to stick a lepard head onto a spear and run at the other tribe of apes with it. It then is said, "He didn't quite know what to do with his new found power, but he was sure he could think of something"
Then at the end of the book when star child approaches earth. All of the nations shoot their nuclear missles at him. He denates them with his mind and then he looks at earth and it is said, "He didn't quite know what to do with his new power, but he was sure he could think of something." It was cute.
The main appeal of the movies and the book is observing the space fetishism that was absolutely infested in pop culture since the moon landing. Humanity had a hope that space would reap some great advancement. Star Trek, 2001, star wars, etc. All had this great incredible hope in space travel. It has died significantly in recent years. And we can look back at the infatuation with space of the 60s and 70s as a quaint nativity. We now are slowly realizing that Science itself is not the sole answer to human advancement. It has extreme limits- such as it having absolutly no say in ethics, which as Plato said was the main purpose in human civilization. The good life, as it were. Humanity, since the scientific revolution has neglected his other disciplines. Like a child that only does his math homework, sure he is good at geometry, but he sucks at biology now lol. Science is good at revealing nature, but it has a stern limit.
Anyway, like the hope of space travel 2001 is stupid and a lie.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>177865088

As I've aged, I have uniroincally come to appreciate The Dawn of Man as an excellent part of the film, equal to the rest. It is not a chore that must be "got through" before one gets to the cool space stuff, which was generally how I thought of it as a kid. It can be watched and enjoyed as a short film in its own right, divorced from the rest of the picture.

It is the simplest story that can possibly be conceived, and it is beautifully shot. There is a simple problem, and there is a conflict with others. If the problem is not solved, the group will surely die. God intervenes. Suddenly, and with great drama, they understand how they can solve their problem. They confront the others, defeat them in battle, and celebrate. The End, if you like, and all without a single word.

Favorite:

Stalker (1979)
The Ninth Configuration (1980)
Alien (1979)
Apocalypse Now Redux
Sunshine/The Thin Red Line


Least Favorite:

Normally I hate a lot of movies but for me to truly hate something, I have to be motivated enough to despise it with every fiber of my being. Anything like capeshit or midwit cinema is too easy to do so I have to choose carefully among the films I hate the most:

For me it's:

>Schnidler's List

I fucking hate Spielberg and his direction toward forcibly pandering us to sympathize with the Holocaust, in addition to the melodramatic music and self-advocating tone of the film.

>Lawrence of Arabia

An inaccurate portrayal of a self-contradictory behemoth who vehemently exploited the hospitality of the Arabs to his own advantage. While the movie would go out of its way to lie to the viewer about his kindness and disposition toward them, he was, in many ways more than one, a smug asshole with no sense of shame or self-regard.

>The Godfather

This is less "hate" and "care" and more about the fact that it puts me to sleep every time I watch it. The movie is so goddamn boring and slow that I can BARELY tell what's going on. While there are some good performances to be had by people like Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Robert Duvall (who is also in Apocalypse Now), these names can't carry the plot if I don't know or can't tell what's going on.

>Dead Poets Society

Gaslights the audience into thinking that suicide is a viable solution towards not achieving your dreams. Fuck this movie. Reminds me of my worst days in private HS that I still am haunted by.

>Any film by Quentin Tarantino that isn't Reservoir Dogs or Jackie Brown

Honestly, fuck the guy. He's basically the Kanye West of films in that he emulates/imitates/duplicates/copies what other films did and uses them to create a pastiche more than a film.

>>177787857

Yes, it has a lot of elements, neo-noir, erotic, horror, but can't really be pinned down to any one. It's a real melting pot kind of film, and a lot of the choices are disorienting, deliberately or not. Like, at one point, with the language and mentally based communication issues, I wondered if the daughter really was the woman he was looking for, the 'mother' was really the daughter who killed the father and then took his place as the abuser, and the guy hung around to try and break the girl's conditioning and rescue her. It wasn't at all. Or if his shoulder wound meant that he was in a loop, or events were out of sequence, imagination, etc. Not those, either! But I like that the film has so much confusion, you're kind of going mad with it, trying to make sense with things that are in front of you but not quite.

>>177825781
See, I had almost the same circumstances as you, I was alone, big headphones, but felt nothing. Any tensions I felt was just waiting for the next loud jumpscare. I actually felt like there was a lot of missed opportunity in making things appear, without fanfare, at the ends of hallways or around corners. But that never happens. Also, the noticeably fake film filter bothered me, as if this was old scratched and dirtied film stock, not camcorder footage or murky low quality digital. Really odd and distracting choice that felt, to me, like it didn't have a lot of thought put into it. I get what he was trying to do, but still weird. I actually appreciate the film going whole hog into a really sensory experience, though, it was just kind of unfocused and bloated to me. A tight 80 minutes may have worked better.

And yeah the face is EXTREMELY reminiscent of the Lake Mungo ghost/premonition thing, especially the face at the very end.

Okay fellas, I just finished Tsui Hark's THE BUTTERFLY MURDERS (1979)

Well I was fucking tricked because this was not particularly /hor/ related, save for several jarring scenes involving the titular butterfly murders, which are played as horrible and frightening, with their screeching cacophony music. But sadly that's it, not even the black armoured stranger is very spooky, he's more of a mysterious figure than menacing.

But, as is typical of Hark flicks, it's dynamic with fun camerawork and characters that keeps the fairly short movie feeling fresh. Also has a bunch of cute girls to keep looking at, especially Green Shadow. The plot, however, about killer butterflies, martial arts espionage, and secret weapons production, completely lost me at a point, but I suspect that was partly the poor out of synch subs as much as it was a messy story. Sadly a rare film, too, the only working public torrent is in 480p.

Watched the Demoniacs, and was disappointed. I'm used to slow burn 70's horror, and French films, but this just dragged. It's also misleading as the blurb gave the impression that the girl's supernatural powers and revenge would be the greater part of the film, which it wasn't at all. The rapes were drawn out, which doesn't bother me if they're hard hitting, or well done, but these were poor, despite the nudity. The acting was bad all around, except for the captain's madness, but even those scenes were repetitive. Also, the lady villain had some great and fucked up dialogue, but was mostly just jiggling around naked. The sex scenes were long and dull. The score was great, and so was the ending, but it's all too bloated to enjoy. There was a lot of filler with random psychic tavern owner, which was very melodramatic but didn't pay off with much.

I'd avoid this one, lads.

>>177841769

So what?

Alien, the Thing and The Exorcist are massively influential, available, and discussed horror films, so many people will encounter them first or early in their horror viewing lives, are often on TV, etc. So, either nostalgia, or beyond nostalgia looking at horror as a whole, those three will often be in best of favourite lists, and deservedly so.

Similar with Blair Witch, especially for people at the time of release.

Texas Chainsaw is a solid pick for slashers, and any one who likes the subgenre will probably pick on of the big three. It would be my pick, too, for its strangeness and beauty, and constant atmosphere.

28 Days is prime example of rage-zombies and fast paced survival horror, also nostalgia pick for many.

Signalman and Mungo have similar themes, anon seems to have an unfortunate preference for FF. Noroi fits into that.

So you have some of the best and strongest examples of horror, with a bias towards FF, with some of the best examples in (mostly aweful) subgenre.

What's your list?

Warwick was a powerful, competent lord who kept getting screwed over by the sides he worked for.
